fields.physical_description: Design: printed card, chromolithographs; reverse sides are printed with an acorn and leaf design in light brown.
fields.title: Period Pieces; antiques game

fields.name:
Type: happy families
Subject: antique houses etc

fields.history_note:
There are 48 cards, 44 of which depict different furnishings from the Jacobean, Georgian, Victorian and Modern periods.  The other 4 cards are `house' cards and they are used as jokers which can be substituted for any other card.  The object of the game is to collect two sets of 3 or 4 objects of the same period or 3 or 4 objects of the same type, ie lighting.

©Dinosaur Publications 1976
fields.production_note: Dinosaur Publications Ltd for the National Trust. ©1976
fields.historical_context_note:
There are 48 cards, 44 of which depict different furnishings from the Jacobean, Georgian, Victorian and Modern periods.  The other 4 cards are 'house' cards and they are used as jokers which can be substituted for any other card.  The object of the game is to collect two sets of 3 or 4 objects of the same period or 3 or 4 objects of the same type, ie lighting.

Rewards: scoring
Forfeits: not scoring
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: cards alone
original box, beige with a gold decorative pattern and an acorn and leaf design

Rules:
HOW TO PLAY:
1.  Seven cards are dealt to 2,3, or 4 players.
2.   The rest of the pack is placed face down.
3.  The top card turned face upwards next to the pack thus staring the discard pile.
4.  Play starts with the player on the dealer's left.  Each player in turn picks up a card from either the discard pile or the pack, examines it and either discards it on the discxard pile or exchanges it for a card already in his hand.
As a player collects a set of 3 cards he may, if he wishes, place them face upwards on the table in front of him and score their total.
Any player, having the fourth card to the set may, in turn, place it in front of himself and score its number.
The game ends when one player has disposed of all the cards in his hand, and at that time scores are totalled.
SCORING
Cards score according to the numbers on them.  House cards score 20.  All cards still in the hand of a player score against him and all cards on the table score for the player who has collected them.  The first player to score 200 (or any greater number chosen by the group of players before play begins) is the winner.
